Jekyll Themes and Markdown Syntax

I decided to go ahead and use a Jekyll theme for my web dev portfolio / blog site. The reason I chose to go this route was based off the time I don’t have to create something from scratch. While at some point in the future I plan to build out an awesome awwwards winning website, right now I just don’t have the time.

For now if you are interested in Jekyll themes I highly recommend them, for their ease of customizing and being able to easily host your website on GitHub Pages for free. I would recommend brushing up on your Markdown syntax to make it easier to write blog posts. Below is a guide that was put together by the creator of this theme. I decided to save it for use on my blog so I can have it for a resource as well.

Headers

H1

H2

H3

H4

H5
H6

Text formatting

  • Bold
  • Italics
  • Strikethrough
  • Underline
  • Superscript
  • Subscript
  • Abbreviation: HTML
  • Citation: — Chester How

Lists

  1. Ordered list item 1
  2. Ordered list item 2
  3. Ordered list item 3
  • Unordered list item 1
  • Unordered list item 2
  • Unordered list item 3

Links

Check out tale on GitHub.

Images

Code and Syntax Highlighting

Use back-ticks for inline code. Multi-line code snippets are supported too through Pygments.

Adding linenos to the Pyments tag enables line numbers.

Blockquotes

Curabitur blandit tempus porttitor. Nullam quis risus eget urna mollis ornare vel eu leo. Nullam id dolor id nibh ultricies vehicula ut id elit.

Horizontal Rule & Line Break

Use <hr> for horizontal rules

and <br> for line breaks.


The end

Markdown guide written by Chester How
